awd_titl_txt: Integration of stress-regulated transcription, mRNA turnover and translation in plants
awd_abstract_narration:
Plants thrive in highly variable environments because of their ability to modulate growth and reproduction in response to environmental factors including light, temperature, oxygen, moisture, and nutrient availability. When environmental conditions are sub-optimal, for example during a drought or flood, plant switch on or off a subset of their genes to control cellular metabolism and adjust development. The molecular processes involved in this switching are not well-understood.  This project will use high-resolution genomic technologies, including ones developed for this study, to define the coordinated regulation of networks of genes in the model plant Arabidopsis thaliana that function under low oxygen stress, a condition associated with flooding. The results will provide a greater understanding of how plants sense and respond effectively to short periods of low oxygen and floods. The genetic resources, methods and datasets spanning multiple steps of gene activity will be a valuable community resource for plant biologists. The research will be carried out at a Hispanic Serving institution where postdoctoral, graduate, and undergraduate researchers will receive interdisciplinary training in biology and bioinformatics. Trainees will also gain experience in teaching and mentoring, and will participate in science communication. The project will develop a lab module for a biology course at a Hispanic-serving community college and engage undergraduates and 5th graders in exciting hands-on research related to agriculture.

Plant responses to external stimuli range from rapid temporal changes in cellular metabolism to seasonal adjustments in development.  These changes are induced by toggling up and down of gene expression at multiple steps, including transcription, mRNA decay, and translation. This project will examine the hypothesis that low oxygen-activated gene transcription fast-tracks mRNAs for translation, limiting their destruction. The study will focus on specific classes of proteins that promote transcription under low oxygen stress or facilitate the turnover of mRNAs. A suite of genomics datasets--including measurements of chromatin accessibility, transcription, mRNA degradation, and translation efficiency--will be collected and analyzed by predictive modeling to obtain an integrated, systems-level view of how plants respond to low-oxygen conditions.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit: Plants must perceive and respond to variations in their environment to grow and reproduce. This project sought to explore the complexities of gene regulatory processes along the path from DNA to messenger (m)RNA to protein, as simplistically described by the ‘Central Dogma’ of molecular biology. In stressful environments, plant genes involved in growth are often turned down as genes that provide protection are activated. The project sought to understand how young plants manage to endure sudden but transient oxygen starvation (hypoxia). Hypoxia is dire for cells of plants and animals because it greatly limits the amount of energy cells can produce for normal biological functions. Hypoxic plant and animal cells die rapidly; if they have access to ample sugars for inefficient energy production they may survive for a short period of time.

By use of highly specialized methods that capture information for all genes at once, we discovered and explored the intricacies of processes that enable plant cells to conserve energy, intensify protection from stress, and prepare for stress recovery. The data answered long-standing questions about how hypoxia-response mRNAs are preferentially decoded by ribosomes whereas many mRNAs important for growth are safely protected. First, we found that instructions in the DNA that determine the proteins (transcription factors) that instruct stress genes to be activated somehow guide the preferential translation of stress-response mRNAs. Second, we showed that growth mRNAs can be safeguarded in the nucleus or cytoplasm during the stress. We know these mRNAs are in protective protein complexes in the cytoplasm until. This later strategy ensures that cells are poised to recover once the stress is alleviated.

Our project also considered how cells determine which mRNAs to retire and recycle into the building blocks of RNA. Focusing on of several avenues of mRNA breakdown, we discovered proteins important in minimizing the abundance of mRNAs associated with the plant immune response. We find immune response transcripts accumulate when the plant is not under stress. We hypothesize that immune response and some other stress genes may be turned on at a very low level, somewhat like a leaky faucet, in the absence of the stress. This may give the organism a head-start upon stress, which may be important for survival of hypoxia or a pathogen. However, plant growth is slow if the stress mRNAs are allowed to accumulate to appreciable levels under non-stress conditions.

Collectively, the project findings contribute to the understanding of stress gene regulation. This information is relevant to breeding or manipulating the ability of crops to survive flooding, pathogens, and other environmental calamities, some of which may be more frequent due to climate change.

Journal articles, methods, genomic data, and other resources from this project are publicly available.

Broader Impacts: This project trained undergraduates, PhD students and postdoctoral researchers. Most of these individuals have chosen careers in science. They include a junior professor at a research university, a junior professor at a technical college, a postdoc at a top-tier research institute and several individuals employed in the biotechnology sector.
